title: LEGCO QUESTION NO.4 (Written Reply)
question_text: Question: It is reported that while 97% of the elderly living in residential care homes are suffering from various dental diseases, the outreaching dental service for the elderly, which commenced last year and was tentatively scheduled to last for one year, might have to terminate when the period expires later this year due to funding problem. In this connection, will the Government inform this Council whether it will consider providing outreaching dental service for the elderly on a permanent basis; if so, the specific details of the plan; if not, the reasons for that?
reply_text:
Madam President, The current Government
policy on dental services is to, through publicity and education, improve people’s
oral health by promoting their oral hygiene awareness, and facilitating the proper use of
oral care services. The Department of Health provides emergency dental services to the
general public, including the elderly population, through 11 Government dental clinics. We
have no plans to separately provide outreaching dental services for the elderly. According to our
understanding, the outreaching dental service referred to in the question is conducted by
the Faculty of Dentistry of the University of Hong Kong. It is a four-year pilot project

the Faculty of Dentistry of the University of Hong Kong. It is a four-year pilot project funded by an external grant. Under the project, a dental care unit was established in July 1998 to provide dental services to people in need and to promote oral health for the prevention of oral diseases. The unit is focusing its service on the elderly at present. While the elderly will continue to be the main group of the unit’s clientele, the unit plans to broaden its service scope to cover other patient groups with dental needs.

Asked by Hon LAW Chi-kwong Date of
